olog.title: Ritual of Not-Knowing: Epistemic Boundaries, Situated Skepticism, and the Ethics of Absence in Synthetic Systems

entities.label: Ritual of Not-Knowing
entities.description: A structured practice or protocol that acknowledges, marks, and ethically engages with the limits of knowledge in complex or opaque systems (cf. Synthetic Ritual Collective, Chang, Black Box Ethics Group).

entities.label: Epistemic Boundary
entities.description: The edge or limit of what can be known, explained, or trusted within a given context (cf. Wong, Cheng et al., Ashby).

entities.label: Situated Skepticism
entities.description: A context-sensitive attitude of critical doubt and reflexive trust calibration in human-AI interaction (cf. Kapoor & Weinberg, Keller & Suchman).

entities.label: Negative Knowledge
entities.description: Awareness of what is not known, unknowable, or absent, and the ability to act responsibly within those limits (cf. Chang, Davies).

entities.label: Situated Learning
entities.description: Acquisition of understanding through participation, context, and legitimate peripheral engagement (cf. Lave & Wenger).

entities.label: Active Boundary Design
entities.description: Interface and protocol strategies that make epistemic limits visible and actionable (cf. Cheng et al., Wong).

entities.label: Governance of Opacity
entities.description: Ethical and institutional frameworks for managing, communicating, and acting within the inherent opacity of synthetic systems (cf. Black Box Ethics Group, Ashby).

morphisms.why: Promotes responsible participation in complex environments.

morphisms.how: Informs ethical frameworks for acting within limits and uncertainty.
morphisms.why: Prevents harm from overreliance on incomplete knowledge.

recursive_refinement.question: What does the ritual of not-knowing enable?
recursive_refinement.answer: Ethical engagement, adaptive trust, and responsible action in the face of epistemic limits.

recursive_refinement.question: What does situated skepticism require?
recursive_refinement.answer: Contextual awareness, reflexivity, and protocols for trust calibration.

recursive_refinement.question: What new entanglement does this produce?
recursive_refinement.answer: A dynamic interplay between knowledge, ignorance, trust, and governance in complex systems.

olog.thesis: The ritual of not-knowing—by marking epistemic boundaries, fostering situated skepticism, and structuring ethical engagement—enables responsible participation in synthetic systems where opacity and uncertainty are inevitable (Chang, Lave & Wenger, Black Box Ethics Group, Ashby).
olog.problem_statement: How can rituals, protocols, and institutional frameworks be designed to support ethical action and adaptive trust in the face of irreducible opacity and epistemic limitation?
vectors_of_influence: Challenges the imperative for total transparency in AI and complex systems.
Enables new forms of ethical engagement, trust calibration, and learning in opaque environments.
Connects to broader debates in epistemology, design, and the philosophy of science (Chang, Lave & Wenger, Ashby, Black Box Ethics Group).
olog.olog_prompt: For any context of not-knowing, identify all agents, boundaries, and protocols; specify all morphisms that mark, enable, guide, or structure ethical engagement; for each, describe what is transformed, how, and why it matters; recursively refine by asking what each process enables or requires, and what new entanglements are produced; conclude with a thesis, problem statement, and connection to broader systems.
